Award.AwardTitle: IMPLEMENTATION PROJECT: Interdisciplinary Experience For Undergraduates in Science, Math. Engineering & Technology (STEM)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Fort Valley State University (FVSU) will strengthen the undergraduate recruitment and retention activities in the STEM disciplines with a second five-year HBCU-UP Implementation Project. This project will advance the mission of the University by providing high quality STEM degree programs that increase the participation of individuals from minority groups in STEM. The expected project outcomes include: 1) increased STEM graduation; 2) increased faculty participation in research, publications, and grants writing; 3) enhanced quality of undergraduate research experiences; 4) strengthened partnerships with academic institutions and private companies; 5) increased use of technology in teaching and research in all STEM disciplines; and 6) increased numbers of STEM students completing the path from high school through college to graduate school.

Intellectual Merit: The project consists of a comprehensive set of activities which will strengthen the overall STEM curricula at FVSU. The development of research infrastructure and partnerships with other institutions and private companies will have an impact on the academic and research programs at FVSU beyond the project period. This project will develop a model for interdisciplinary collaborations in research and curriculum particularly suitable for small teaching institutions.

Broader Impact: The project will produce better prepared, competitive, students for the STEM workforce and establish a pipeline of students into graduate and professional programs. This program will serve as a recruitment and retention tool for the institution and enable FVSU to gain visibility as a student-centered institution that provides opportunities for undergraduate student research. The NSF REU-Site in biotechnology and Collaborative Summer Internship with major institute programs in STEM at FVSU can serve as a model for other minority serving institutions seeking to promote undergraduate mentoring and research programs in STEM. Through cross-disciplinary links and links to larger universities and laboratories, FVSU will create an exemplary program that will provide sustainable research experiences for students and a fulfilling research environment for faculty.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Fort Valley State University (FVSU) has made a sustained commitment to its mission and strategic plan of providing quality educational experiences for underrepresented minority students, who constitute 93% of enrolled students (4,000). We remain steadfast in strengthening the undergraduate recruitment and retention in the STEM disciplines. The goals will be achieved via achievement of several interrelated activities such as: introduction of interdisciplinary biotechnology and forensic majors, interdisciplinary curriculum and research infrastructure for faculty and students in STEM disciplines, continued tutorial assistance in gate-keeping bottleneck courses and inclusion of laboratory hands-on-experience, undergraduate student participation in research, and by conducting summer internships at major research institutions. The expected project outcomes include: 1) increased STEM graduation with emphasis in biotechnology, forensic science, chemistry and biochemistry, agricultural sciences and  bioenergy ; 2) increased faculty participation in research, publications, and extramural support for faculty research and teaching efforts; 3) enhanced quality of undergraduate research experiences at partner academic and private institutions; and 4) increased numbers of STEM students completing the path from high school through college to graduate school.  Over the period 2007-2011, 12 different faculty and staff served as research mentors to 185 REU students in the on-campus summer and academic year REU programs.  Program accomplishments were disseminated at several meetings.  Bolstered by past HBCU UP support, the STEM faculty members wrote joint proposals to USDA, NSF, and Department of Education and received more than $2M Federal funding to strengthen the STEM program.  Our STEM faculty has established collaborative research projects with a number of major institutions where FVSU undergraduates conducted summer internships in STEM disciplines.  Several of them have published work as co-authors and had earned degrees in biological sciences. Fifty eight of the participants pursued graduate degrees at 12 institutions in 10 states and other 39 pursued careers that ranged from homeland security and the pharmaceutical industry to federal research institutions. As a springboard to graduate and professional education, this program has proven quite successful with emphasis on the demographic composition of the program. Now and in future FVSU will strive to maintain the diversity and balance representation.
